comments:
CIS 441 focuses on cyber physical systems with emphasis on real-time issues.
Cyber physical systems are integrations of computation and communication with physical
processes. Embedded computers monitor and control physical processes in real- time. As
these embedded computers transform from word processors to global communications
devices for information gathering and sharing, embedded computers will change from
small self-contained systems to cyber-physical systems. The course focuses on the
principles, methods, and techniques for building high-assurance cyber-physical systems.
Topics include requirements capture and modeling, mental models, assurance cases,
hazard analysis, real-time programming and communication, real-time scheduling and
virtual machines, feedback control in computer systems, verification and valid series of
projects that implement safety-critical embedded systems (e.g., pacemaker, infusion
pump).
Students for the most part felt that they could have learned more from this course.
While some of the topics were interesting, others were not as engaging and could have
been restructured to be more informative and more in-depth. However, students did enjoy
the projects in the course.
At certain times throughout the course, students felt that Professor Lee could have
done a better job explaining the concepts during lecture.
This course was described to have “the right amount” of work. The major projects
of the course, though rewarding, required a lot of time and were challenging to complete.
The only prerequisite for this class is CIS 240 or an equivalent course. The completion of
ESE 350 is also recommended.
